title-group.article-title: A preliminary study using luminol-enhanced intraoperative bile duct imaging technique in rabbits

contrib-group.aff: 2https://ror.org/020vvc407grid.411549.c0000 0001 0704 9315Department of General Surgery, Faculty of Medicine, Gaziantep University, Gaziantep, Turkey

abstract.p: In the literature, a variety of techniques are recommended for intraoperative biliary tract imaging. The objective of this study was to develop a more cost-effective and widely applicable technique that could serve as an alternative to existing imaging techniques by taking advantage of the chemiluminescence effect of luminol. An experimental study using rabbits was designed. The rabbits in the control group received isotonic solution, while the other groups were administered various concentrations of luminol chemical solutions with catalyst and activator chemicals. Biliary tract imaging was conducted using chemiluminescence in the biliary tract during luminol injection, and the resulting images were recorded. The intraoperative imaging of bile ducts in rabbits was successfully achieved through the utilization of the chemiluminescence effect of luminol. The statistical analysis of the laboratory results and histopathological examination revealed no statistically significant difference between the groups used with varying concentrations of luminol and other chemicals and the control group. The methodology employed in this study is cost-effective, readily accessible, and straightforward to implement. In light of these findings, we posit that this technique may serve as a potential alternative to existing methods in the future.

funding-source.institution: Gaziantep University Scientific Research Projects Unit

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Cholecystectomy is indicated in a wide spectrum of diseases in which gallbladder function is impaired, particularly gallstone disease. These include cholecystitis, choledocholithiasis, Mirizzi syndrome, Bouveret syndrome, gallbladder polyps, porcelain gallbladder, biliary pancreatitis, and gallbladder cancers1. It is estimated that approximately 20 million individuals in the United States are affected by gallstone disease, with cholecystectomy being performed in hundreds of thousands of patients annually2. The laparoscopic technique for cholecystectomy is now regarded as the gold standard worldwide3,4.

Despite a decline in the incidence of biliary tract injury during laparoscopic cholecystectomy in recent years, the rates remain higher than those observed in open cholecystectomy procedures5. Biliary tract injuries result in recurrent cholangitis attacks, secondary biliary cirrhosis, liver failure, and anastomotic strictures, leading to prolonged treatment processes and hospitalizations. These complications significantly impair the patient’s quality of life and cause high morbidity6,7. These processes result in considerable expenditure for the healthcare system. Furthermore, the surgeon may be subject to legal ramifications. In order to minimize these complications, international guidelines have been prepared by surgical societies with the objective of determining and implementing appropriate strategies. A comprehensive review of the literature reveals that biliary tract imaging is a crucial step in difficult cholecystectomies where the biliary tract anatomy cannot be clearly demonstrated8,9. The literature describes intraoperative cholangiography, laparoscopic ultrasonography, and intraoperative infrared imaging techniques for intraoperative biliary tract imaging10–12.

In this study, a novel imaging technique was investigated as a potential alternative to existing intraoperative biliary tract imaging techniques in the literature. The technique was evaluated in experimental rabbit models. The chemiluminescence effect of luminol was employed in the preparation of solutions containing luminol and a variety of catalysts and activators, which were then injected into the gallbladders of rabbits for the purpose of biliary tract imaging and to elucidate the effects of the chemical on tissues.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: A total of 12 rabbits were used in the study, and the rabbits were divided into four paired groups, with three rabbits in each group. The control group was named D, and the other groups were named A, B, and C. Regarding the histologic activity index of the rabbits, five rabbits (41.7%) had a histologic activity index of 6, and three rabbits (25%) had a histologic activity index of 4.

There was no statistically significant difference in the histologic activity index between the groups (p > 0.05). The histologic activity index of two rabbits (66.7%) in group B was 4, and the histologic activity index of two rabbits (66.7%) each in group A and group C was 6. The histologic activity index of rabbits in Group B was lower than that of Group A and Group C.

Pancreas, biliary tract, and duodenum tissues obtained from all rabbits were subjected to the same procedures and histopathologically evaluated. No signs of inflammation were found in all specimens. There was no difference between the rabbits in terms of tissue damage in the pancreas, bile ducts, and duodenum. In addition, renal parenchyma samples were evaluated for interstitial nephritis in terms of possible nephrotoxic effects, and no evidence of nephritis was found in any rabbit.

When the results of laboratory changes were analyzed, it was found that mean values of AST, ALT, urea, creatinine, and platelet increased, while mean values of ALP, total bilirubin, LDH, CRP, WBC, and hemoglobin decreased. The mean value of direct bilirubin was found to be the same (Table 1).

caption.p: Changes in laboratory results before and after the experiment.

sec.p: When groups analyzed the median changes in laboratory values, no statistically significant result was obtained (p > 0.05) (Table 2).

caption.p: Changes in laboratory results by groups.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Intraoperative biliary tract imaging techniques represent an effective method for the prevention of iatrogenic injuries to the biliary tract, as recommended by international guidelines5,8. A comprehensive review of the literature reveals the existence of three distinct imaging techniques: The intraoperative techniques in question are cholangiography, infrared imaging, and laparoscopic ultrasonography. These techniques are frequently employed by general surgeons, particularly in the context of challenging cholecystectomies. The selection of an appropriate technique is dependent on a number of factors, including the advantages offered by each technique, as well as the surgeon’s experience and preferences.

The efficacy of various imaging techniques, particularly intraoperative cholangiography, in minimizing biliary tract injuries and healthcare expenditures has been substantiated by empirical evidence13. In a comprehensive meta-analysis conducted by Rysted and colleagues, which encompassed over two million patients, it was demonstrated that intraoperative cholangiography is an effective method for detecting biliary tract injuries and reducing healthcare costs associated with such injuries. In light of these findings, Rysted et al. advised that intraoperative cholangiography should be performed routinely during cholecystectomy14. Laparoscopic ultrasonography and intraoperative infrared imaging are high-cost techniques due to the necessity of additional equipment. In our study, the market value of the luminol chemical utilized was 66.7 euros, while the market value of the contrast agent employed in intraoperative cholangiography was approximately 50 US dollars15,16. When we consider that the quantity of luminol obtained at the price mentioned above point would be sufficient for the technique to be applied to hundreds of patients, it becomes evident that the technique in question is less costly than intraoperative cholangiography in terms of financial outlay. The advantages of this technique, including ease of application, accessibility, the absence of a device requirement, and the absence of X-ray exposure, can be considered advantages over intraoperative cholangiography in the future.

The use of laparoscopic ultrasonography in practice is very limited and is only performed in certain centers by surgeons skilled in the technique. Dili et al. reported in a meta-analysis that laparoscopic ultrasonography was superior to intraoperative cholangiography in patients with difficult biliary anatomy17. In a study by Hublet et al., laparoscopic ultrasonography was superior to intraoperative cholangiography in the detection of gallstones and prevention of biliary tract injuries18. Intraoperative infrared imaging is another intraoperative biliary tract imaging technique that is quite costly and very limited in its use. In a meta-analysis of 2221 patients, Liu et al. reported that intraoperative infrared imaging was associated with shorter operative time, superiority in defining the biliary tract, and decreased conversion to open surgery and hospitalization compared with the control group19. Lim et al. compared infrared imaging with intraoperative cholangiography in a study that included seven studies and 481 patients. They reported that infrared imaging was safer and more successful in showing the biliary tract20. In order to make a comparison between laparoscopic ultrasonography and intraoperative infrared imaging and the technique we applied in our study, the technique should be applied to humans, and more data is needed. However, the practical limitations and learning difficulties of laparoscopic ultrasonography and the practical limitations and high cost of intraoperative infrared imaging should be kept in mind. Therefore, it has not been possible to put these methods into routine use today.

There are not enough studies on the toxicology of luminol in the literature. In a study on rats, the lethal dose (LD50) value was calculated as > 500 mg/kg (14). Sanders et al., in their study on luminol metabolism and toxicology in rats, administered luminol to rats at different doses (0.5/5/50 mg/kg) and by different routes. They reported that almost all of the luminol administered orally and intravenously in rats, regardless of the dose given, was rapidly absorbed from the gastrointestinal system and removed from the body with urine (90%) and feces (10%). There was no accumulation in tissues, and they did not expect any significant toxic effect in humans since luminol metabolism is similar in humans21. In our study, we injected 0.0005 mg, 0.001 mg, and 0.002 mg of luminol intrabiliary into rabbits in groups A, B, and C, respectively, all of which weighed approximately 3 kg. When the lowest dose of luminol administered by Sanders et al. is compared with the dose of luminol in our study, we see that at least 1000 times lower dose of luminol was administered in our study. Therefore, we did not expect any luminol-induced toxic effect or accumulation in the tissues in our study.

Sakorafas et al. 72 patients and Bickel et al. 1034 patients, it was concluded that there was no significant increase in liver function tests after laparoscopic cholecystectomy22,23. Hasukic et al. reported that total bilirubin, ALP, GGT, and LDH values did not change, while AST and ALT values increased moderately after laparoscopic cholecystectomy24. Güven et al. reported that the increase in AST, ALT, GGT, and LDH levels in patients undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy was more pronounced due to pneumoperitoneum compared to open technique25. Saber et al. reported that AST and ALT levels increased more in laparoscopic cholecystectomy compared to open technique, but this increase was not clinically significant in patients without liver failure26. In a retrospective study in which Wewelwala et al. investigated the effect of intraoperative cholangiography on postoperative liver function tests (ALT, ALP, GGT) and included 177 patients, they reported that ALT and GGT increased more in patients who underwent intraoperative cholangiography in laparoscopic cholecystectomy compared to patients who did not undergo intraoperative cholangiography27. In our study, there was an average increase in AST and ALT values, an average decrease in ALP values, and no change in GGT values after surgery in experimental animals. We found no statistically significant change between the groups for all these values.

In a retrospective study including 324 patients who underwent intraoperative cholangiography, Mattila et al. reported that the radiation dose to X-rays was negligibly low28. In intraoperative cholangiography, contrast-induced nephropathy is negligible. In a study by Shinoura et al., it was reported that bile duct visualization with contrast material within 72 h following contrast-enhanced computed tomography was associated with nephropathy, especially in patients with high creatinine values before the procedure29. However, cholangiography-related acute tubular necrosis cases are rarely encountered in the literature30,31. In our study, there was an average increase in urea and creatinine values studied in serum samples taken from all rabbits before and 48 h after surgery, but there was no statistically significant change between the experimental groups. In addition, we did not find any findings in favor of nephropathy in all groups in tissue samples taken from the kidneys of all rabbits 48 h after surgery. However, we think that the moderate increases in creatinine and urea in all experimental groups together with the control group may be due to surgical stress and postoperative nutritional changes.

In a study published by Butt et al., a total of 54 patients who underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy were observed. Following the surgical procedure, a decrease in hemoglobin, hematocrit, and platelet values was noted, accompanied by an increase in leukocyte values. In the same study, an elevated leukocyte count was linked to a response to trauma32. In our study, we observed a mean reduction in hemoglobin and leukocyte levels and an increase in platelet values in the experimental animals. Nevertheless, no statistically significant difference was identified between the experimental groups with regard to these values.

Zarrinpar et al. performed intraoperative infrared imaging with different doses of indocyanine green on 37 patients, and no complications were reported33. Esposito et al. examined 43 patients who underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy in a prospective study and reported no complications in the infrared imaging group34. Shaaban et al. reported that laparoscopic ultrasonography was completely safe in their study35. Alvarez et al. reported that no intraoperative cholangiography-related complications and organ damage developed in 11,423 patients who underwent routine intraoperative cholangiography in laparoscopic cholecystectomy36. In our study, we measured hemogram, urea, creatinine, total bilirubin, direct bilirubin, AST, ALT, ALP, GGT, CRP, LDH values in all groups of rabbits before and 48 h after the experiment. There was no statistically significant change in any laboratory values in the luminol-treated groups compared to the control group. In addition, tissue samples taken from the pancreas, liver, biliary tract, duodenum, and kidney from all experimental rabbits 48 h after surgery were subjected to histopathologic examination, and no histopathologically significant difference was found in terms of tissue damage between the control group and the groups in which different doses of luminol and other chemicals were administered.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: Ethics committee approval was obtained from Gaziantep University Animal Experiments Local Ethics Committee for the study (meeting dated 08.09.2022, protocol no: 277). Experimental animals were observed under veterinary control in a laboratory environment with appropriate conditions. In the study, the legal regulations and ethical principles determined for experimental animals were strictly followed. All procedures performed on animals were carried out in accordance with ARRIVE guidelines and legal regulations. The design of the study, experimental procedures and all other stages were designed in accordance with ARRIVE guidelines.

Given the anatomical similarity to the human biliary tract and the feasibility of surgical procedures, New Zealand White rabbits were selected as experimental animals. The rabbits used in this study were obtained from the Experimental Animal Research Center of Çukurova University, Adana, Turkey. Twelve female rabbits, aged between one and three years, with a weight range of three to five kilograms, were placed in cages at the Gaziantep University Experimental Animals Application and Research Center. The 12 rabbits were randomly assigned to one of four paired groups, with three rabbits in each group using Excel software. The groups were randomly assigned alphanumeric identifiers, with Group D designated as the control group. The rabbits were assigned numerical identifiers within each group. Each rabbit was maintained in its own cage throughout the experiment. The rabbits were observed for 15 days prior to the commencement of the experiment. Signs of disease in the rabbit, pregnancy and death were determined as exclusion criteria. During the period mentioned above, all rabbits exhibited no indications of malnourishment or disease. The cages were illuminated for 12 h per day, alternating between light and darkness throughout the entirety of the monitoring and experimental period. For all rabbits, the experiment was performed by the same surgical team, with equal equipment and for equal times.

Prior to experimentation, blood samples were collected from the ear veins of all rabbits. The results of the hemogram, urea, creatinine, total bilirubin, direct bilirubin, aspartate aminotransferase (AST), alanine aminotransferase (ALT), alkaline phosphatase (ALP), gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT), and c-reactive protein (CRP) tests, as well as those of the lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) test, were recorded in the database. Blinding technique was used to record the results.

In addition to luminol (C8H7N3O2), sodium hydroxide (NaOH) was used to make the medium alkaline, potassium ferricyanide (K3[Fe(CN)6] was used as a catalyst, and hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) was used as an oxidizer (Table 3). The chemicals were sterilized using the ethylene oxide technique. Four different solutions containing different concentrations of luminol and other chemicals were prepared. Solution A, 0.25 g luminol and 1 g sodium hydroxide dissolved in 500 mL distilled water; Solution B, 0.5 g luminol and 1 g sodium hydroxide dissolved in 500 mL distilled water; Solution C was obtained by dissolving 1 g luminol and 1 g sodium hydroxide in 500 mL distilled water; Solution D was obtained by dissolving 1.25 g potassium ferricyanide and 3 g hydrogen peroxide in 500 mL distilled water (Table 4).

Following the preparation of the solutions, the surgical procedure was initiated. Once all rabbits had been placed in the supine position, a combination of ketamine (35 mg/kg) and xylazine (5 mg/kg) was administered intramuscularly for the purpose of sedation. Once the rabbits had been fully sedated, the surgical field was prepared by removing hair, and antisepsis was achieved with povidone-iodine. Following the appropriate surgical draping, the abdomen was accessed through a midline incision above the umbilicus (Fig. 1). The liver, gallbladder, and bile ducts were then examined. Following the cannulation of the gallbladder with a double-lumen cannula, 2 mL of distilled water was injected simultaneously through different cannulas in rabbits in Group D, 1 mL of solution A and 1 mL of solution D in rabbits in Group A, 1 mL of solution B and 1 mL of solution D in rabbits in Group B, and 1 mL of solution C and 1 mL of solution D in rabbits in Group C. Subsequent to the acquisition of images during injection, the abdominal folds were closed in accordance with the anatomy, and the surgical procedure was terminated.

The injection of luminol-containing solutions into the gallbladder of rabbits in groups A, B, and C was successfully recorded with a camera in the dark (Fig. 2), allowing for the observation of the irradiation in the biliary tract. Group D, which served as the control group, was not administered luminol or other chemicals.

caption.p: Intraoperative gallbladder and bile duct visualization with luminol. (a) Gallbladder, (b) biliary tract, (c) hydropic gallbladder.

sec.p: Following the procedure, the rabbits were transferred to their own cages and observed for a period of 48 h. At the 48-hour follow-up, no mortality and no indications of severe disease were observed in the rabbits. Following a 48-hour follow-up period, all rabbits underwent a second surgical procedure, during which the abdomen was explored in accordance with the initial surgical plan. A second blood sample was collected for analysis, and the blood parameters that had been monitored prior to surgery were re-examined. The findings were documented in the database. Tissue samples from the liver, biliary tract, duodenum, kidney, and pancreas were obtained from all rabbits for histopathologic examination. The tissue samples were subsequently preserved in formaldehyde. After the experiment was completed, all rabbits were re-administered the anaesthesia (ketamine-xylazine combination) doses before euthanasia. Complete loss of consciousness and anaesthesia were confirmed by observing the absence of corneal reflex, eyelash reflex and rhythmic breathing. Then the diaphragm was cut and the heart was accessed. Exsanguination technique was applied through the incision made in the heart. All euthanasia steps were performed according to the American Veterinary Medical Association (AVMA) Guidelines for the Euthanasia of Animals (2020).

The tissues obtained from the rabbits were evaluated in the presence of an expert pathologist (Fig. 3). The pathologist was blinded to the study to ensure unbiased assessment. Tissue samples from the liver were scored using the “histologic activity index” criteria37.

caption.p: Microscopic images of liver specimens. (a) A3 rabbit; (b) B2 rabbit; (c) C3 rabbit; (d) K2 rabbit (Hematoxylin-Eosin staining, 200x magnification).

sec.p: Statistical Analysis: The data were transferred to IBM SPSS.23 (IBM Inc., Chicago, IL, USA) and evaluated by statistical analysis. Before statistical analyses, it was checked whether there were no data entry errors and whether the parameters were within the expected range. Normality assumptions of continuous variables were analyzed using the Kolmogorov-Smirnov test, and homogeneity of variance was analyzed using Levene’s test. Mean and standard deviation values were given in descriptive statistics of continuous variables. Kruskal Wallis-H Test was applied for comparisons with 3% or more normal distribution. The chi-square test was applied to analyze categorical data. In all analyses, p < 0.05 was accepted as the significance level.

Safety and Toxicity: Luminol is a chemical molecule that exhibits chemiluminescence when mixed with a suitable oxidizing agent. Soluble in many polar organic solvents but insoluble in water, it is available as a white to pale yellow powder. Luminol is absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract, rapidly metabolized, and excreted in the urine. In addition, luminol and its metabolites do not accumulate in tissues. 90% of enterally administered luminol is excreted in the urine and the rest in the feces, all of which are removed from the body within 24 h38. Potassium ferricyanide is mainly used in the paint industry, photography, and mining industry. It has low toxicity in humans, and although its toxic effects occur in direct contact with concentrated solutions of the compound, it can be prevented by taking temporary and simple precautions39,40. Hydrogen peroxide is a chemical frequently used in the pharmaceutical and food industry and is recognized as safe by the FDA. It is usually used in 3% concentration solutions. High-concentration solutions may pose a danger to human health after oral ingestion41. Sodium hydroxide is a basic chemical soluble in water. In case of inhalation, it may cause cough and sore throat; in case of skin contact, skin redness, pain; in case of eye contact, blurred vision, eye redness; in case of ingestion, vomiting, abdominal pain, and serious side effects42,43 (Table 3). The mean LD50 value was used to assess the toxic effects of chemicals44.

To mitigate the potential toxic effects of chemicals, protective goggles, aprons, and other protective equipment were utilized during the preparation of chemical solutions and their subsequent application to experimental rabbits. Prior to the commencement of the experiment, the environment in which the experiment would be conducted was prepared in accordance with the requisite surgical conditions and sterilization rules. All chemicals to be used were subjected to the requisite precautions in light of the potential for toxicity (Table 5).

caption.p: Toxic effects of chemicals and LD50 values.

tr.td: It may cause skin, eye, and respiratory irritation on contact
It may cause cough, sore throat if inhaled; skin redness, pain if in contact with skin; blurred vision, eye redness if in contact with eyes; vomiting and abdominal pain if swallowed
It may cause eye and skin irritation on direct contact, mild cough and sore throat on inhalation, redness and pain on contact with skin and eyes, abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting on ingestion
High concentrations of solutions may cause toxic effects on oral intake

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The objective of this study was to develop a novel technique that could serve as an alternative to the existing intraoperative imaging techniques employed in cholecystectomy. The chemiluminescence effect of the chemical luminol was successfully employed for intraoperative bile duct imaging in experimental rabbits. The statistical analysis revealed no statistically significant difference between the rabbits exposed to luminol and other chemicals and the rabbits in the control group with regard to both blood results and histopathological results. The technique employed in this study is cost-effective, readily accessible, and straightforward to implement. It is our contention that this technique may prove to be a viable alternative to existing techniques in this regard.

sec.title: Limitations of the study
sec.p: The present study is not statistical; rather, it is a preliminary investigation of a novel surgical technique. The existing literature does not provide sufficient data on the potential toxic effects of the chemicals used in our study on rabbits. In accordance with the 3R principle, the number of subjects was kept to a minimum to minimize the number of experimental animals. Consequently, the statistical outcomes are inadequate. Furthermore, the rabbits were observed for 48 h post-experiment to assess the study’s efficacy, which may be considered inadequate for evaluating long-term outcomes. Notwithstanding the limitations mentioned above, the present results suggest that the study can be safely applied in larger animal groups and that the technique is promising for future use in humans.

notes.title: Author contributions
notes.p: MG and AA designed the study and the animal experiment and carried out all the procedures. MG, AA and ABA contributed to the first draft of the manuscript, wrote the manuscript and critically revised the manuscript for important intellectual content. MG, AA, ASB and HG carried out the animal experiment. ASB and HG contributed to the monitoring of the vital signs of the experimental animals in the laboratory environment before and after the experiment, and to the nutrition and care of the experimental animals. ABU and LY contributed to the study design and the first draft of the manuscript, edited the language and critically reviewed the manuscript for important academic content. OE performed the histopathological examination and statistical analysis. All authors read and approved the final version of the manuscript.

notes.title: Funding
notes.p: Financial support was received for this study from Gaziantep University Scientific Research Projects Unit (Project Number: TF.UT.22.69).

notes.title: Data availability
notes.p: The datasets analysed during the current study are available from the corresponding author on reasonable request.

notes.title: Competing interests
notes.p: The authors declare no competing interests.

notes.title: Ethics approval
notes.p: Ethics committee approval was obtained from Gaziantep University Animal Experiments Local Ethics Committee for the study (meeting dated 08.09.2022, protocol no: 277).
